Award.AwardTitle: Full-Scale Development: My Sky Tonight: Early Childhood Pathways to Astronomy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP) and its collaborators are conducting a set of research and development activities focusing on early childhood astronomy in the first field-wide effort to increase the capacity of informal science education (ISE) institutions to effectively engage their youngest visitors (ages 3 - 5) in astronomy. Leading the project is an Action Research Group comprised of the ASP; experts in cognitive development, early childhood, and astronomy learning progressions from UC Santa Cruz, Cal Poly San Luis Obispo, and Penn State; and the Lawrence Hall of Science at UC Berkeley, Children?s Discovery Museum of San Jose, and San Luis Obispo Children?s Museum as sites for research, field testing, and implementation.

The project will identify critical areas of focus for early childhood astronomy and will test the hypothesis that early astronomy learning is not only possible but may contribute to a more sophisticated understanding of the domain. A key question is: How can the ISE field scaffold children's early curiosity and ideas about astronomy to position them for greater understanding and interest in the topic? The results of the research and the materials that are created for educators will receive broad distribution nationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My Sky Tonight is a collaborative program and research initiative focused on engaging 3- to 5-year-old children in science practices through hands-on astronomy activities. This research-practice partnership included astronomy educators and activity developers from the Astronomical Society of the Pacific; experts in cognitive development, early childhood education, and astronomy education from the University of California Santa Cruz, California Polytechnic Institute San Luis Obispo, and Pennsylvania State University; and early childhood educators at the Lawrence Hall of Science (CA), Children's Discovery Museum of San Jose (CA), San Luis Obispo Children's Museum (CA), and Discovery Space of Central Pennsylvania (PA).

The My Sky Tonight project team created a set of research-based, hands-on astronomy activities that are rich in science practices and designed to be developmentally appropriate for pre-K children, covering topics such as changing shadows, Moon phases, day and night, and space exploration. We also created supporting materials and resources for the educators who facilitate the activities, including short instructional videos and guides to engaging young children in science. These materials are all freely available at www.astrosociety.org/MySkyTonight

227 educators from 190 museums, parks, and libraries across the U.S. received toolkits with all of the physical materials needed for the My Sky Tonight activities. Each of these educators also participated in a six-week online training workshop focused on developmentally appropriate techniques for engaging young children in science practices using the My Sky Tonight activities.

In addition to these activities and trainings, the My Sky Tonight team has also advanced the knowledge base in early STEM learning through a series of research studies. This research extends our understanding of the use of science practices in informal settings with young children. Most informal science educators are able to describe ways young children may engage in science practices in their venues (Plummer, Crowl, & Tanis Ozcelik, in review). Yet, when we observed informal science educators with preschool-age audiences, we found practitioners ranged from offering no opportunities to engage audiences in science practices to those who provided extensive opportunities through investigations of science phenomena. This points to the importance of our professional development opportunities and MST activities designed to support science practices. Findings from a study of an expert informal science educator implementing four My Sky Tonight activities - designed to support young children's investigation of astronomical phenomena - found that 3-to-5 year old children co-constructed evidence-based explanations for science phenomena and used evidence to support modeling practices across all activities (Plummer & Ricketts, 2018).

My Sky Tonight research also extends our understanding of children's engagement with astronomy and other science-related ideas in their spontaneous conversations at home, in museum visits with their families, and in preschool settings. We found that preschool-aged children from a variety of backgrounds expressed interest in astronomy-related topics such as where the Sun goes at night, how the Moon stays up in the sky, and why the stars shine (Jipson, Callanan, Castaneda, Hamilton, & Zumbro, 2017). We also found that parents varied in how likely they were to spontaneously engage in forms of science-related talk with their children, but that this variation is not necessarily predicted by factors such as the parents' educational background (Castaneda, Rodriguez-Gutierrez, Callanan, & Jipson, under review). In fact, children whose parents had lower formal education were found to ask more explanation-seeking questions in everyday conversations about nature than did children whose parents had higher levels of education (Callanan, Solis, Castaneda, & Jipson, 2018).

In the final year of the project, the My Sky Tonight project team also created an illustrated children's book made possible as a result of supplemental funding from NSF. Breakfast Moon is the story of Mae and her younger brother, Arthur, who look for the Moon in the sky each morning and then record their observations in their Moon Journal. The ASP has published this book, and in addition to individuals purchasing the book, we have also distributed it to hundreds of museums and parks across the U.S. We've also incorporated the book into our research studies. Our research in progress is exploring the role of storybooks in encouraging families' conversations about astronomy. Ongoing analysis further suggests that the use of narrative elements from a storybook can be used to support science practice by providing context, content, and investigation questions (Cho & Plummer, 2018).

The MST team of educators, activity developers, and researchers is eager to continue working together on future projects that will build on this work. We are planning to more deeply explore the role of storybooks and other forms of story in supporting young children's engagement in science, with an improved design-based research model for creating stories and activities and measuring their impact on children.
